title: 108_s2584
content: The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" allows for a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 provides a 50 percent credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities based on the basis of qualified value-added agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year. The credit is allocated among eligible persons in a farmer-owned entity on a pro rata basis. The Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 offers a maximum credit of $30,000 for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities for property placed in service during the taxable year. The credit is reduced by creditable investments allowed for the year. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is limited to the eligible person's creditable investments in the entity. Creditable investments are the qualified investments made by the eligible person in the entity, reduced by certain amounts. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is limited to the eligible person's investments in the entity, reduced by qualified investments made in other farmer-owned entities. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is limited to $30,000 of aggregate qualified investments made by the eligible person. Qualified value-added agricultural property is defined as specific property. The term 'qualified value-added agricultural property' refers to property used to add value to goods derived from organic matter, including agricultural crops, wastes, wood residues, and animal wastes, and eligible for depreciation under section 168 without regard to useful life. The term 'eligible person' refers to someone actively involved in an eligible farming business, owning and operating property with a useful life of 3 years or more, and eligible for depreciation under section 168. The term 'eligible person' refers to someone actively involved in an eligible farming business and materially participates in the trade or business of farming. The determination of material participation is similar to that under section 2032A(e)(6) for individuals, corporations, cooperatives, partnerships, estates, or trusts. The term 'eligible farming business' refers to a farming business that is not a passive activity and is defined in section 263A(e)(4). The determination of eligibility is made at the shareholder, partner, or beneficial interests level for corporations, cooperatives, partnerships, estates, or trusts. Additionally, a 'farmer-owned entity' is defined as an entity owned by farmers. A farmer-owned entity is defined as a corporation or partnership where eligible persons own at least 50% of the voting power and stock or profits interest. A farmer-owned entity is defined as a corporation or partnership where eligible persons own at least 50% of the voting power and stock or profits interest. The ownership criteria include owning 50% or more of the total voting power and profits interest in the entity, as well as 50% or more of the member patronage interests in a cooperative. The family members of an individual for constructive ownership rules include only spouse, children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and spouses of children. The term 'qualified investments' refers to investments that meet specific criteria. The term 'qualified investments' refers to a payment for the purchase of a qualified equity interest in a farmer-owned entity, which includes stock in a domestic corporation acquired by the taxpayer between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. Between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011, qualified investments include acquiring stock in a domestic corporation, a capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, or a patronage interest in a cooperative solely in exchange for cash. Between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011, qualified investments include acquiring stock in a domestic corporation, a capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, or a patronage interest in a cooperative solely in exchange for cash. Special rules apply for married individuals filing separately. For qualified value-added agricultural property, the credit amount is reduced to $15,000 from $30,000. Rules similar to section 52 and 50(b) apply for allocation and eligibility. Basis adjustment is made if the credit is allowed to an eligible person. The credit allowed for qualified value-added agricultural property reduces the property's basis by the credit amount and increases it by any recapture under subsection (e). Recapture rules apply if the property is disposed of within a 5-year period after the credit is allowed. The qualified value-added agricultural property ceases to be qualified if it is disposed of, no longer meets eligibility criteria, or is no longer in service. The eligibility of an entity or farmer-owned entity under this section ceases if they are no longer eligible. Special rules apply in the event of death, where the eligibility period is suspended for 2 years after the person's death. If an heir is also an eligible person, they can elect to continue the eligibility period. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for this section, and it will not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2010. Section 38(b) of the Code is amended to define the current year business credit. Section 38(b) of the Code is amended to define the current year business credit, including the value-added agricultural property investment credit for eligible persons. Additionally, the credit allowable against minimum tax is expanded to include the value-added agricultural property credit. The Code is amended to include the value-added agricultural property credit, defined as the credit determined under section 45G. The value-added agricultural property credit, as defined under section 45G, is included in the Code. Additionally, a conforming amendment allows for the inclusion of the value-added agricultural property credit in certain sections of the Code. A limitation on carryback of the value-added agricultural property investment credit is also specified. No carryback of value-added agricultural property investment credit before effective date. Unused business credit attributable to section 45G cannot be carried back to years before enactment of section 45G. The text introduces a new paragraph (11) related to the value-added agricultural property investment credit under section 45G. Additionally, there is a basis adjustment in section 1016 of the Code regarding payments with a credit allowed under section 38. The text introduces a new paragraph (11) related to the value-added agricultural property investment credit under section 45G. Additionally, there is a basis adjustment in section 1016 of the Code regarding payments with a credit allowed under section 38. In section 45G(d)(3), payments with a credit under section 38 are addressed. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to qualified investments and property placed in service after December 31, 2004.
